I owned WDC for more than 10 yrs and i think you are spot on. My plan is also to hold at this level and sell opportunistically at much higher price. And in the meantime, dabble into Micron which i hv never owned before.

Afaik HDD's are at a technological bottleneck. They cant increase bit-density any further unless they finally get that heat/microwave based write/read tech going and even then, the uplift will only keep them around for 2 more generations or so due to physically running out of space on the platters.Meanwhile ssd's do not have this issue and will continue to cheapen in $/tb. The performance difference stopped being even remotely comparable a decade ago as well.Call me crazy but imo Seagate and now WD are digging their own grave not participating in the clearly vastly superior technology.And the superior technology will be the superior market as well. It is inevitable.HDD's may have a use now, but thats solely based on being cheaper. Not exactly a high margin buisness you wanna be in when your products only reason for existing is that the better version is more expensive and thats on a timer.All of the above is why I invested in Micron when considering the constantly growing storage demand due to AI and other technological trends and it has done very well for me.I intend to continue sticking with them for my storage needs, altough I may build a NAS with WD Red's in the future but even that'll have some crucial ssd's for cache, so 50/50 hdd/ssd I guess.
